column1: #Text=After reading Ms Turpel-lafond's article, I'm not sure what she is actually asking for.
#Text=My personal experience living across the street from a reserve is that many of the problems are internal.

#Text=I watched an 11 or 12 year old girl be sexually assaulted by an older male reserve member and when I called the police, they said they could only attend the reserve if someone on the reserve called.
#Text=So I stood there in the rain, yelling at the man who had assaulted the young girl and he told me to mind my own business and go away.
#Text=From my perspective, no amount of money will make the problem of abuse of young girls go away until the attitude on the reserves changes.
#Text=Last week there was an article in the Globe titled 'The best native leader Canada never had.'
#Text=It profiled Chief Clarence Louie of the Osoyoos band.
#Text=Unless there has been no residential school abuse of his band, what is the difference between his band and all the other bands?
#Text=It seems it is a lack of leadership.
#Text=Yes, I want this awful abuse to stop happening, but throwing more money at the problem doesn't seem to be the answer.
#Text=It has to be a change of culture within each individual band.
#Text=I've met some really strong native women who know what needs to be done, but they are being undermined by a bad, sexist culture on the reserves.
#Text=Tossing dollars at the problem won't help.
#Text=Turpel-Lafond, give us something more concrete call to action that just another inquire.
#Text=And please tell me why the Osoyoos band works when others do not.
